byline.original: By BENJAMIN WEISER, SUSANNE CRAIG and WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM

abstract: Preet Bharara, United States attorney who has presided over successful trials against former New York State legislators Sheldon Silver and Dean G Skelos, says in interview that trials offered window into combination of factors that have led to culture of corruption in Albany; states examination of evidence presented in trials should give insight into how to fix culture in Albany, although Bharara declines to offer concrete solutions or specific reforms.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Bharara, whose office recently won convictions of two of New York’s most powerful legislators, said Albany’s problems were deep and systemic, but declined to suggest specific reforms.

headline.main: Preet Bharara, U.S. Attorney, Sees Lessons in Albany Corruption Trials
headline.print_headline: U.S. Attorney Says Trials Offer Solutions to a Corrupt Albany

snippet: Mr. Bharara, whose office recently won convictions of two of New York’s most powerful legislators, said Albany’s problems were deep and systemic, but declined to suggest specific reforms.
